sentences: Ferry Corsten (Dutch pronunciation: [ˈfɛri ˈkɔrstə(n)]; born 4 December 1973) is a Dutch DJ, record producer and remixer from Rotterdam.
section: N/A

sentences: He is well known for producing many pioneering trance tracks during the 1990s–2000s under his numerous aliases, including System F, Moonman, Pulp Victim and Gouryella.
section: N/A

sentences: In recent years, he has shifted to a broader electronic music style, playing everything from progressive house to uplifting trance; and hosts his own weekly radio show, Resonation Radio.
section: N/A

sentences: Corsten routinely plays at events and festivals all over the world including Electric Daisy Carnival, Tomorrowland, and many others, and has been consistently ranked among DJ Mag's Top 100 DJs poll, having placed at rank 5 in 2004 and 2005, 6 in 2006 and 2008; and most recently at 53 for 2020.
section: N/A

section: == Career == | === Early years ===
== Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Ferry Corsten was born in Rotterdam, Netherlands.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: As a child, he would listen to a Dutch radio show called "The Soulshow", which played different selections of electronic music including disco and soul music.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Whenever he heard a track that he liked, he would go to the record store and purchase it.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: His first experience in DJing was when he was 15 years old at that time when he was playing at his school parties.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: As a teenager he saved money to buy his first keyboard by washing cars, and selling mix tapes to kids in his neighborhood.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: He was inspired by Ferry Maat and Ben Liebrand for his mixes.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: He eventually released a record with a couple of friends when he was just sixteen years old and later began releasing self-made productions while he grew up in Rotterdam in the 1990s, producing underground hardcore gabber tracks, later expanding into club-house and trance music.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: During these years, Corsten also studied to become an electrical engineer.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: In 1995, under the name Hole In One and aged just 21 years old, he won the prestigious De Grote Prijs van Nederland award, which recognized his contribution to The Netherland's electronic dance music scene.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: In 1996, while still living in his parents' home, Corsten made his debut at the United Kingdom Singles Chart with his single "Don't be Afraid" under the pseudonym Moonman which ranked at #46.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: This was his very first major European achievement as a solo dance artist, producer and composer.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: 1997 saw the release of "Interspace" (a collaboration between Corsten and Peter Nijborn as Discodroids), and his first singles under the Pulp Victim alias: "I'm Losing Control", which was a limited vinyl-only release, and "Dreams Last For Long".
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: The latter two were followed a year later by "The World", a track that contained vocals by Maire Brennan and got re-released in 1999 with some brand new remixes, including his remix under the Moonman alias.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Also in 1997, Corsten and his partner Robert Smit established a dance label named Tsunami with the Dutch-based dance company Purple Eye Entertainment b.v., this junction made the creation of another label possible; Polar State.
section: == Career == | === Early years ===

== Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Under the guise of Albion, Ferry Corsten produced a track titled "Air".
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Signed and released by Platipus Records in April 1998, the song became a top seller for the label and was championed by John Digweed and Paul Oakenfold who licensed it for their Global Underground compilations.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Due to its continued popularity, it was re-released two years later, with new remixes by Oliver Lieb, Hybrid and The Swimmer.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: The same year Corsten finished his track "Out of the Blue" which, after being in promo for over 6 months, was released in February 1999 on the Tsunami imprint under the name System F.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: The track became a worldwide hit, achieving a top twenty position in the UK Singles Chart.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: The follow-up single, "Cry", a collaboration between Corsten and Robert Smit, also reached the UK Top 20.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: A trance hit, "Out of The Blue" formed spear tip of Corsten's trance sound – one that was quickly galvanized by co-productions like Gouryella's "Gouryella" (with Tiësto) and Veracocha's "Carte Blanche" (with Vincent de Moor).
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: The track "Gouryella" was released in May 1999 and became a huge hit scoring various chart positions around the world, including a top fifteen position in the UK Singles Chart.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: The next single, entitled "Walhalla", also made it on the charts worldwide, peaking at No. 27 in the UK Singles Chart.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Released through the Tsunami imprint, both singles went on to be certified Gold on record sales.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Corsten's club and chart success as an artist and producer led him to become an in-demand remixer for both underground and high-profile artists.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Summer 1999 saw the release of Gatecrasher Wet, the third compilation album by Sheffield-based club Gatecrasher, which included his remixes of Cygnus X's "The Orange Theme", Matt Darey's "Liberation" and The Generator's "Where Are You Now?".
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: In addition to his massively successful remix of Art of Trance's "Madagascar", Corsten was asked to remix several singles, including William Orbit's arrangement of "Adagio for Strings", Push's "Universal Nation", Faithless's "Why Go?", and Moby's "Why Does My Heart Feel So Bad?" as well as "New Year's Day" for U2.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: His remix of Barber's "Adagio For Strings", released in late 1999, was awarded at the 2000 Dancestar Awards for best remix of the year of 1999.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Also in 1999, Corsten was elected "Producer of the Year" by Muzik Magazine at the Ericsson Muzik Awards in London and, in his home country, received the Zilveren Harp music award for his numerous contributions made to Dutch dance music.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Ferry made his debut on DJ Magazine's Top 100 DJs Poll in the same year at the #77 position.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Aside from producing, he began compiling and mixing the Trance Nation series for Ministry of Sound.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: His first installment (which went Platinum) became a commercial success, selling over 400,000 copies and charting for three weeks at number one in the UK Compilation Chart.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Furthermore, Corsten made a mix compilation album together with Robert Smit called Tsunami One.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: In September 2000 the third Gouryella single entitled "Tenshi" was released.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: On March 9, 2001 Tsunami released "Soul On Soul", a collaboration between System F and Marc Almond, the singer of Soft Cell.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: "Soul On Soul" is taken from the System F album Out Of The Blue and it got released including remixes by Barthezz, Kay Cee, Elektrochemie LK and The Hacker.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: The same year Corsten produced the official theme song for the legendary Dutch dance festival Dance Valley and collaborated with Armin van Buuren for "Exhale".
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Released via Tsunami, both tracks reached Gold status.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: Also in 2001, he made remixes for "Clear Blue Water" by Oceanlab, "Catch" by Kosheen and "Arms of Loren" by E'voke.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: In 2002, Corsten contributed to remix projects of tracks by Japanese superstar Ayumi Hamasaki.
section: == Career == | === 1998–2002: Out of the Blue and Trance Nation ===

sentences: He went on to compose and arrange her heavily trance-based song "Connected", which was released in 2003, along with remixes, as a single in Germany, selling 4 million copies.

sentences: In 2010, Ferry Corsten was on mixing duties for an edition of BBC Radio 1's Essential Mix and a remixed album of System F tracks entitled, Champions came out in February.

sentences: Corsten's interactive radio show, Corsten's Countdown has become available to listen to across more than 40 countries via more than 210 radio stations worldwide.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: Corsten released his compilation, Once Upon a Night in 2010, which hit number one on iTunes in the U.S.

sentences: The album came out on March 30 and he eventually started his tour: Once Upon a Night: The Experience.

sentences: After the release of Vol.1, Ferry released Once Upon a Night Vol.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: 2 on October 1, and his world tour started on September 17.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: Corsten hosted a New Year's Eve event at the O2 Academy Brixton, London in 2011 in which he delivered the midnight set and went on to perform back-to-back with other successful Trance DJ's/producers, such as Judge Jules, Sied van Riel, Marcel Woods, to name a few.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: In February 2012, Ferry Corsten released a full-length artist album, WKND (Flashover Recordings), comprising notable songs including "Not Coming Down" (featuring Betsie Larkin); "Live Forever" (featuring Aruna); "Ain't No Stoppin'" (featuring Ben Hague); "Brute" with Armin van Buuren; "Check It Out" and "Feel It".
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: The album was distributed by Ultra Records in the US.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: Ferry Corsten stars in a series of professionally produced, original videos titled WKNDR (pronounced "weekender") where he speaks directly to viewers from various scenes around the world.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: The WKNDR series shows Corsten backstage and onstage at large nightclub and concert venues as well as festivals; the series also takes viewers into his private studio for a behind-the-scenes look at music production.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: The 250th episode of Corsten's Countdown (April 11, 2012) was broadcast live, worldwide, for the duration of the unprecedented eight-hour show beamed out from the studios of Sirius XM Radio in New York City.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: The Corsten's Countdown show is aired in more than 40 countries and the CC250 broadcast became a Twitter trending topic three times during that eight-hour broadcast during which time Ferry Corsten took live requests from around the world via a specially designed interactive website, Twitter and Facebook.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: In May 2012, Ferry Corsten launched a new monthly mixshow titled Ferry's Fix.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: Unlike his Corsten's Countdown show which is weekly, Ferry's Fix is a monthly mixshow.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: Also, unlike Corsten's Countdown, Ferry's Fix is a straightforward DJ mix (whereas Corsten's Countdown is an interactive "countdown" styled show).
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: Corsten wrote a tune with Chicane and Christian Burns in July 2012 called "One Thousand Suns," an emotive trance tune that has received airplay from the likes of Armin van Buuren and a very positive fan reaction based on listener call-ins to his weekly Corsten's Countdown radio show.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: On August 31, 2012, Ferry Corsten debuted his "Full On (Hosted by Ferry Corsten)" live show concept in North America at Roseland Ballroom in New York City for the official afterparty for the music festival, Electric Zoo.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: Ferry's Full On concept was a series of back-to-back sets with other well-known trance artists taking place at festivals and venues all over the world; including Tomorrowworld, Stereosonic, and Space Ibiza.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2014: Once Upon a Night and WKND ===

sentences: In November 2012, Corsten released the third installment to his Once Upon A Night compilation series on Premier (a label joint venture between Flashover Recordings and Black Hole Recordings).

sentences: The physical release was a double-disc release.

sentences: The broadcast was heard worldwide on partner radio stations in more than 40 countries and also on the interactive website.

sentences: After several spontaneous back to back performances in early 2013, Ferry Corsten and German producer Markus Schulz announced they would be producing and touring together as the new duo, New World Punx.
